newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK may rezone industrial land for residential use.
newsitem.headline: HK may rezone industrial land for residential use.

text.p: Hong Kong could rezone some surplus industrial land for residential use, the government's director of planning, Peter Pun, said on Tuesday.
But Pun said determining how much could be rezoned required consideration of factors including the infrastructure, traffic, environment, and ownership situation of each site.
"So up to this point in time, we cannot tell you exactly where and when and how much land can be rezoned from industrial to residential," he told reporters.

Pun said Hong Kong had 560 hectares of existing and planned industrial land for general industrial uses, half of which had been developed, but said government-commissioned consultants had forecast the need for industrial land would fall to 260 hectares by 2001 and 250 hectares by 2011.
"On the face of it, we will have a surplus of 300 hectares of land for general industrial uses," Pun said.

But the surplus would be between 115 and 140 hectares after taking into account additional land required for new industrial developments which will be more land-intensive and to meet new planning standards, and general industrial land being considered for conversion to special industrial use, he added.

Moreover, consultants had forecast a deficit of 185 hectares by 2011 of land for special industrial uses, relating to purpose-designed, owner-occupied premises needed for emerging high-value-added and high-technology industries, Pun said.
"In this respect, the government is actively planning the fourth industrial estate and a science park. We are also looking into the concept of a business estate," he said.
Pun said consultants had recommended that a sufficient stock of industrial land be maintained to facilitate Hong Kong's long-term development.

Despite Hong Kong's transition to a service-oriented economy, PUn said the manufacturing industry employed 18 percent of the workforce in 1995 and accounted for 9.2 percent of the gross domestic product.
